awd_titl_txt: Modern Aspects of Multivariable Operator Theory and Matrix Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Operator theory and matrix analysis are both fundamental areas of mathematics. In large part, they were originally developed to provide a theoretical basis for quantum mechanics and other physical phenomena. An increasing number of application areas have emerged as a result of breakthroughs in operator theory and matrix analysis, which testify to their underlying importance to science and engineering. The areas of application closest to the research in this project are control systems engineering, electrical engineering, signal processing, image processing, and quantum computation. The principal investigator will build on his past work to further develop the interplay between the subdisciplines of free function theory, operator completions, statistical signal processing, matrix inequalities, and optimization. To accomplish this goal the principal investigator will continue existing collaborations as well as develop new ones, and engage actively with both graduate students and undergraduate students in the emerging research. The principal investigator will continue to maintain an intellectual environment fostering student involvement and development, providing the students with the skills, experience, and confidence to successfully pursue a career in the mathematical sciences. Thus, the project will yield both new, impactful mathematical results, as well as highly trained mathematicians prepared to join the scientific and educational workforce crucial to this nation.
   
Many questions in system and control theory, filter design, signal and image processing come down to function theoretic questions. The case of several variables is a highly active research area where the techniques of multivariable operator theory are highly effective. The specific themes of the current project include (i) Matrix completions, (ii) Moment problems, (iii) Free function theory, (iv) Realizations, (v) Determinantal representations, (vi) Numerical range and radius, and their generalizations, (vii) Hypergeometric functions, and (viii) Inverse eigenvalue problems. This combination of areas will lead to new avenues of research that are of interest to different research groups. All projects also have a computational component, allowing for the implementation of the results and the potential to be used by researchers in all areas of science and engineering.  The principal investigator will continue running an Analysis Seminar at Drexel University featuring local and international researchers, as well as Drexel students. The principal investigator and his students will disseminate the results via conference presentations and publications in a variety of leading mathematical journals and preprint servers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored challenges in multivariable operator theory and matrix analysis, along with their applications. The project's research contributions span several areas, from reproducing kernel theory and optimization to quaternionic numerical ranges, all of which have potential applications in machine learning, optimization, and quantum computation. In parallel with these theoretical advancements, the project incorporated a significant training and professional development component, involving both graduate and undergraduate students in the research process.

Research Outcomes

One of the core aspects of this research involved exploring the well-known theory of reproducing kernels from Hilbert spaces in the more general setting of Banach spaces. Reproducing kernels have been a pivotal tool in machine learning, particularly in support vector machines and kernel methods. However, working within the constraints of Hilbert spaces limited the range of problems that could be addressed. By broadening the framework to include Banach spaces, new possibilities emerge for dealing with more intricate problems, while retaining much of the powerful theory associated with reproducing kernels. This setting of reproducing kernel Banach spaces allows the study of optimal interpolation problems within specific spaces, including Hardy and Bergman spaces on various domains. These results provide insights into optimality conditions and interpolation theory, with potential applications in both theoretical and applied mathematics, particularly in areas related to machine learning.

In a separate line of investigation, the project addressed long-standing open problems involving hyperbolic polynomials, which are central to optimization and related fields. Hyperbolic polynomials play a crucial role in hyperbolic programming, appearing as feasibility sets for optimization problems. A key focus was the generalized Lax conjecture, which asks whether every hyperbolic polynomial can be represented by a positive definite linear determinantal form. This conjecture is important for understanding the geometry of optimization problems and for developing efficient algorithms. Our research made significant strides by furthering connections between hyperbolic polynomials, stable polynomials, and multivariable operator theory. This work lays the groundwork for future research in optimization and convexity, with the potential to impact fields such as control theory and computational mathematics.

Another major result from the project involved the study of numerical ranges. Specifically, we showed that the c-numerical range of a non-scalar skew-Hermitian quaternion matrix is convex, resolving an open problem. Additionally, we explored the behavior of functions related to eigenvalues of matrices and their applications to higher rank numerical ranges. Notably, we derived new trace-type conditions for when these numerical ranges are disks centered at zero.

We also studied classes of multivariable functions which are well approximated on compacta by the geometric mean of the eigenvalues of a unital (completely) positive map into a matrix algebra or more generally a type II_1 factor. We showed that in three or more noncommuting variables, the classes are different, due to the recently established failure of the Connes embedding conjecture. The question of whether approximability holds for scalar inputs led us to formulate the new shuffle-word-embedding conjecture.

Finally, we addressed computational issues in semidefinite programming (SDP). One of the major outcomes of this research was a method to bound the maximum rank over all solutions in SDP problems, which led to new insights into convergence rates for certain classes of central paths. This has important implications for optimization in both theoretical and applied settings, especially in areas such as control theory and signal processing. 

Training and Professional Development

 A key goal of the project was to engage graduate and undergraduate students in research, fostering their professional development and enhancing their research skills. The Principal Investigator (PI) mentored six graduate students and five undergraduate students, providing them with hands-on experience in mathematical research. The students participated in a range of activities, including posing new research questions, performing numerical experiments, reading and interpreting academic papers, and developing writing skills to communicate complex ideas clearly.

Most importantly, the students had the opportunity to contribute to original research and bring their findings to publication, further enhancing their academic development. This immersive experience in research helped the students acquire valuable skills in both mathematics and scientific communication, preparing them for future careers in academia and industry.

Conclusion

The outcomes of this NSF-funded project have contributed significantly to the advancement of multivariable operator theory and matrix analysis, with applications ranging from machine learning to optimization. Through the exploration of new mathematical frameworks, such as reproducing kernel Banach spaces and hyperbolic polynomials, the project has expanded the theoretical understanding of these fields. Moreover, the inclusion of students in this research has provided them with invaluable training, equipping them with the skills necessary to become the next generation of leaders in mathematics and related disciplines. The project's impact extends beyond the research itself, as it has fostered a collaborative and inclusive environment for both students and researchers, contributing to the growth and diversification of the mathematical sciences community.
